isis.stitle: DT 466 / DT 530 Engine Diagnostic Manual for 4000 Series Trucks (2001) - MECHANICAL DIAGNOSTICS DT 466 and DT 530 - HARD START / NO START DIAGNOSTICS - Engine Cranking RPM

entry.para: Use a DMM to measure engine cranking speed for 20 seconds: For procedure 1 or 2 below.
1. Connect breakout tee ZTSE4486 between CMP sensor and CMP sensor harness connector. Measure rpm or Hz at connector pin C and ground. See figure F on back of form.
2. Connect breakout box to engine harness connector on ECM. Measure voltage at Breakout Box pins (51+ & 19-). See figure E on back of form.
If rpm is not shown, recheck DTC's and see CMP diagnostics.

figure.caption: Measuring Cranking Speed at CMP Sensor

svcsubproc.title: Purpose

note.para: When using a DMM in the 4 cycle RPM mode the meter reading must be divided by 12 to equal the actual rpm of the engine. When reading Hertz (Hz) the meter reading is 1/5 the actual rpm. 26Hz = 130 rpm.

svcsubproc.para: To determine the correct engine cranking speed to start the engine. Use the following test procedure if the Electronic Service Tool (EST) is unavailable or fails to function correctly. Low battery power or an electronic failure may inhibit the EST from receiving diagnostic data.

svcsubproc.title: Test Procedure

para.emph: Test must be performed with fully charged batteries.

svcsubproc.para: Engine cranking rpm must generate the required ICP to operate the fuel injectors and to create enough compression to ignite the fuel.

svcsubproc.title: Measuring Cranking rpm with Breakout Tee

warning.para: To avoid personal injury, be certain that the transmission is in neutral, parking brake is applied, and drive wheels are blocked prior to cranking engine.

step1.para: Connect Breakout Tee (ZTSE4486) between CMP sensor and CMP sensor harness connector .
Place DMM negative probe (black) onto a good engine ground.
Place DMM knob to the V / RPM setting, then toggle to select RPM or Hz in the display.
Crank engine for a minimum of 20 seconds and measure engine cranking rpm (Hz) at CMP signal green connector (C).
Record engine cranking speed on the diagnostic form.

svcsubproc.title: Measuring Cranking RPM with Breakout Box

step1.para: Remove engine connector (60 pin) from the ECM.
Install Breakout Box (ZTSE4445) adapter connectors to the engine and chassis female connections on the ECM. Reconnect engine harness connector to the Breakout Box adapter connector.

note.para: Torque connector to ECM to 50 in·lbs (5.65 N·m).

step1.para: Connect the (+ lead) of the Digital Multimeter (DMM) to terminal 51 and the (- lead) to terminal 19. Select the V / RPM setting, then toggle to select RPM or Hz in the display. See Measuring Engine Cranking rpm with Breakout Box .
Crank the engine and check the DMM. A minimum of 130 rpm (26 Hz) is necessary to start the engine.
Record cranking engine rpm on diagnostic form EGED-220.

figure.caption: Measuring Engine Cranking RPM with Breakout Box

step1.para: If DMM indicates 0 frequency/rpm during engine cranking, the ECM will not receive a signal from the CMP sensor. See CMP sensor diagnostics, in Section 3, Electronic Control System Diagnostics.
If the CMP sensor is not functioning, it must be replaced. The ECM will not allow the Injector Pressure Regulator (IPR) valve to fully activate without a CMP signal.

note.para: If no frequency/engine rpm is measured with the DMM, check for DTC's. See Test 5 or Test 8 and Camshaft Position (CMP) sensor diagnostics.

item.para: Low cranking rpm - Starting system electrical malfunctions, incorrect oil grade, or long oil change intervals in cold ambient temperature conditions.

No engine rpm - Poor electrical connection at CMP sensor connector for wiring harness, wiring harness to sensor (open or shorted), or a defective CMP sensor will cause a 0 frequency / engine rpm indication.
Electronic Service Tool (EST) with Master Diagnostics software
If DTC's are set, see DTC column on Engine Diagnostic Trouble Codes .

para.emph: No engine rpm indication during cranking - See CMP sensor diagnostics

item.para: Camshaft Position Sensor and Circuit Diagnostics
